MEDICAL.summary: It is legal for certified medical marijuana patients to possess cannabis in New York State. Patients registered with the state's Medical Cannabis Program may possess up to a 60-day supply of medical cannabis, as determined by their healthcare provider, and may possess more than the general adult-use limit if medically necessary.

This right is established by the Marihuana Regulation & Taxation Act (MRTA) and enforced by the Office of Cannabis Management (OCM).

MEDICAL_GROW.summary: It is legal for certified medical marijuana patients and their designated caregivers to cultivate cannabis at home in New York State, provided they comply with state regulations. Patients and caregivers who are at least 21 years old (or 18 and older as of 2025) and registered with the Medical Cannabis Program may grow up to three mature and three immature plants per person, with a household cap of six mature and six immature plants. Cultivation must occur at a private residence, plants must be secured and not visible to the public, and all cannabis produced is for personal medical use only. The regulatory framework is established by the Marihuana Regulation and Taxation Act (MRTA) and implemented by the Office of Cannabis Management.
MEDICAL_GROW.gov_quote: Certified patients and designated caregivers 21 years of age or older who are registered with the Medical Cannabis Program may cultivate cannabis at home for the patient’s personal use. Each certified patient or designated caregiver may cultivate up to three mature and three immature cannabis plants at any one time, with a maximum of six mature and six immature plants per private residence, regardless of the number of patients or caregivers residing there.
